The British Standard . ), subtitle: (

Need American English?{" "} AP & Chicago standards use title case.

Switch to US â†’
), description: "The British standard for government (Gov.uk), BBC, and Oxford academic writing. Automatically converts text to pristine British sentence case.", defaultTools: ["case"], }} sections={[
In the United Kingdom, readability is paramount. From the{" "} NHS Digital Service Manual to the{" "} GOV.UK design system, sentence case is the standard for digital communication. Why? Because it is 20% faster to scan than Title Case.

The Rules of British Sentence Case:

  • Capitalise the first word: Just like a standard sentence.
  • Capitalise proper nouns: Names (London), Organisations (BBC), and Acronyms (NASA) remain uppercase.
  • Lowercase the rest: Minor words, important wordsâ€”it doesn't matter. If it's not a name, keep it down.
, ]} /> ); }

Title capitalisation is complex. Does "is" get capitalised? (Yes, it's a verb). What about "after"? (It depends). Our{" "} smart converter follows the strict rules of the major American style guides so you don't have to memorise them.

Supported Standards:

  • AP Style: The gold standard for journalism and news.
  • Chicago Manual: Perfect for book titles and long-form essays.
  • APA Style: The requirement for academic papers and science journals.
  • NYT Style: The classic, prestige headline format.

import { BookOpen } from "lucide-react"; import { GraduationCap } from "lucide-react"; export function EducationalSection() { return (
Why CorrectCase?

The British English vs American English{" "} capitalisation gap

Most text tools blindly apply American title case rules. But British publications like the BBC and{" "} The Guardian use sentence caseâ€”a fundamentally different standard.

{/* Comparison Panel */}
{/* BBC Style */}
ðŸ‡¬ðŸ‡§

BBC style

British English sentence case

"The prime minister announces new climate policies for the UK"

Only the first word and proper nouns capitalised

{/* NYT Style */}
ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸

New York Times style

American English title case

"The Prime Minister Announces New Climate Policies for the UK"

Major words capitalised per AP/Chicago style

{/* The Gap */}

The problem

Existing tools were built for American audiences and fail to recognise British English conventions. International copywriters working with British clients need accurate sentence case conversionâ€”not approximations or manual corrections.

CorrectCase is the first tool built from the ground up to handle both standards correctly, with awareness of British grammar, hyphenation rules, and SI unit formatting.

); }
